articles.headline: Retail Sales Rise for Third Month, Though Growth Slows
articles.snippet: The increase was a sign that consumerism remained resilient, but the recovery has been buoyed by government assistance that expired at the end of July.
articles.abstract: The increase was a sign that consumerism remained resilient, but the recovery has been buoyed by government assistance that expired at the end of July.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as coronavirus infections continued to spread, in-person school reopening plans were scrapped and unemployment stayed near record highs, Americans kept shopping in July with retail sales rising 1.2 percent from June, reflecting a rare bright spot in the battered economy.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: How Apple’s 30% App Store Cut Became a Boon and a Headache
articles.snippet: App makers like the game company Epic and the music service Spotify are challenging Apple’s right to a large cut of their sales. Regulators have taken notice.
articles.abstract: App makers like the game company Epic and the music service Spotify are challenging Apple’s right to a large cut of their sales. Regulators have taken notice.
articles.lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Twelve years ago, Apple introduced the App Store, a peculiar online marketplace for the year-old iPhone. It had 500 offerings. Apple told app makers it would take a 30 percent cut of their sales, and few complained.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas

articles.headline: Postal Service Warns States It May Not Meet Mail-In Ballot Deadlines
articles.snippet: The agency suggested allowing at least 15 days to request a ballot, fueling further criticism that it was making it harder to vote during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: The agency suggested allowing at least 15 days to request a ballot, fueling further criticism that it was making it harder to vote during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Postal Service has warned states that it may not be able to meet their deadlines for delivering last-minute mail-in ballots, further fueling the clash over the new postmaster general’s handling of vote-by-mail operations as President Trump continued to rail against the practice.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater, Hailey Fuchs and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: As Colleges Move Classes Online, Families Rebel Against the Cost
articles.snippet: Schools face rising demands for tuition rebates, increased aid and leaves of absence as students ask if college is becoming “glorified Skype.”
articles.abstract: Schools face rising demands for tuition rebates, increased aid and leaves of absence as students ask if college is becoming “glorified Skype.”
articles.lead_paragraph: After Southern California’s soaring coronavirus caseload forced Chapman University this month to abruptly abandon plans to reopen its campus and shift to an autumn of all-remote instruction, the school promised that students would still get a “robust Chapman experience.”
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: ‘We’re Clearly Not Doing Enough’: Drop in Testing Hampers Coronavirus Response
articles.snippet: For the first time during the pandemic, the United States saw a downward trend in the number of coronavirus tests conducted each day.
articles.abstract: For the first time during the pandemic, the United States saw a downward trend in the number of coronavirus tests conducted each day.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months, public health experts and federal officials have said that significantly expanding the number of coronavirus tests administered in the United States is essential to reining in the pandemic. By some estimates, several million people might need to be tested each day, including many people who don’t feel sick.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Kamala Harris, Daughter of Immigrants, Is the Face of America’s Demographic Shift
articles.snippet: Her parents’ arrival to Berkeley as young graduate students was the beginning of a historic wave of immigration from outside Europe that would change the United States in ways its leaders never imagined.
articles.abstract: Her parents’ arrival to Berkeley as young graduate students was the beginning of a historic wave of immigration from outside Europe that would change the United States in ways its leaders never imagined.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Kamala Harris’s mother left India for California in 1958, the percentage of Americans who were immigrants was at its lowest point in over a century.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Postal Crisis Ripples Across Nation as Election Looms
articles.snippet: President Trump’s furious objection to mail-in balloting and a new Trump-allied postmaster general are raising fears about the election and the Postal Service.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s furious objection to mail-in balloting and a new Trump-allied postmaster general are raising fears about the election and the Postal Service.
articles.lead_paragraph: DARBY, Pa. — Each day, when Nick Casselli, the president of a Philadelphia postal workers union, sits down at his desk on Main Street in this historic town where trolley cars still run and the post office is a source of civic pride, his phone is full of alarmed messages about increasing delays in mail delivery.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater, Jack Healy, Michael D. Shear and Hailey Fuchs

articles.headline: The Cop Was the Hero in One Viral Video. Another Told a Different Story.
articles.snippet: Bobby White was celebrated as the “Basketball Cop” after millions saw a video of him shooting hoops with local teenagers. A recording from two years earlier shows him throwing a young Black man on the hood of his car during an arrest.
articles.abstract: Bobby White was celebrated as the “Basketball Cop” after millions saw a video of him shooting hoops with local teenagers. A recording from two years earlier shows him throwing a young Black man on the hood of his car during an arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Aahtrell Johnson remembered the police car rolling up, just before he was about to take his shot at the basket under the pine trees. It was 2016, and his neighbor had called 911, complaining that he was getting loud in the street. A white officer named Bobby White had been sent to respond.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: Shifting Dynamics of the Mideast Pushed Israel and U.A.E. Together
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Netanyahu’s quest to open relations with Arab countries without settling the Palestinian conflict long seemed quixotic. External events changed the equation.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Netanyahu’s quest to open relations with Arab countries without settling the Palestinian conflict long seemed quixotic. External events changed the equation.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu buoyantly approached the microphone, beaming at his diplomatic coup.
articles.byline: By David M. Halbfinger and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Nursing Homes With Safety Problems Deploy Trump-Connected Lobbyists
articles.snippet: Nursing homes, the center of the pandemic, are seeking tax breaks, federal cash infusions and protection against lawsuits.
articles.abstract: Nursing homes, the center of the pandemic, are seeking tax breaks, federal cash infusions and protection against lawsuits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some want direct government aid. Others want tax breaks. Many want protection against lawsuits.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Trump’s Policies Are a Boon to the Super Rich. So Where Are All the Seven-Figure Checks?
articles.snippet: Only a small fraction of the president’s top donors from 2016 have given as much to his re-election effort.
articles.abstract: Only a small fraction of the president’s top donors from 2016 have given as much to his re-election effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: Timothy Mellon, reclusive heir to a Pittsburgh banking fortune, was such an unknown figure among Republican operatives that they needed to Google his name when he reached out in 2018, unexpectedly, to offer his help in the midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Karen Yourish

articles.headline: Pelosi to Recall House for Postal Service Vote as Democrats Press for DeJoy to Testify
articles.snippet: The House will cut short its summer recess to consider legislation that would counter changes at the Postal Service that critics say undermine casting ballots by mail.
articles.abstract: The House will cut short its summer recess to consider legislation that would counter changes at the Postal Service that critics say undermine casting ballots by mail.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California announced on Sunday that she would call the House back from its annual summer recess for a vote this week on legislation to block changes at the Postal Service that voting advocates warn could disenfranchise Americans casting ballots by mail during the pandemic.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Where Has Your Tween Been During the Pandemic? On This Gaming Site
articles.snippet: Millions of children have flocked to the online gaming site Roblox since March. That’s helping game developers, some as young as 16, make a lot of money.
articles.abstract: Millions of children have flocked to the online gaming site Roblox since March. That’s helping game developers, some as young as 16, make a lot of money.
articles.lead_paragraph: When her middle school closed in March, Garvey Mortley stopped going to lacrosse practice and playing drums in the school band. With so much time at home, she leaned into another interest: Roblox, an online gaming site and app with Lego-like characters and millions of virtual worlds to explore.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning

articles.headline: It’s Convention Time: 2-Minute Speeches, No Pomp, a Forlorn Milwaukee
articles.snippet: The Democratic convention starts Monday. But none of the leading participants will be in Milwaukee, the host city. Hotels there were closed and the bars of America’s most beer-loving city were eerily barren.
articles.abstract: The Democratic convention starts Monday. But none of the leading participants will be in Milwaukee, the host city. Hotels there were closed and the bars of America’s most beer-loving city were eerily barren.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Tonight’s DNC Schedule, Streaming and Speakers.]
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: A Private Security Company Is Detaining Migrant Children at Hotels
articles.snippet: Under emergency coronavirus orders, the Trump administration is using hotels across the country to hold migrant children and families before expelling them.
articles.abstract: Under emergency coronavirus orders, the Trump administration is using hotels across the country to hold migrant children and families before expelling them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration has been using major hotel chains to detain children and families taken into custody at the border, creating a largely unregulated shadow system of detention and swift expulsions without the safeguards that are intended to protect the most vulnerable migrants.
articles.byline: By Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: The Week Old Hollywood Finally, Actually Died
articles.snippet: The streaming services are in charge, and bringing a ruthless new culture with them.
articles.abstract: The streaming services are in charge, and bringing a ruthless new culture with them.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, the best thing about being a Hollywood executive, really, was how you got fired. Studio executives would be gradually, gently, even lovingly, nudged aside, given months to shape their own narratives and find new work, or even promoted. When Amy Pascal was pushed out of Sony Pictures in 2015, she got an exit package and production deal worth a reported $40 million.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Europe’s Big Oil Companies Are Turning Electric
articles.snippet: Under pressure from governments and investors, industry leaders like BP and Shell are accelerating their production of cleaner energy.
articles.abstract: Under pressure from governments and investors, industry leaders like BP and Shell are accelerating their production of cleaner energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: This may turn out to be the year that oil giants, especially in Europe, started looking more like electric companies.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed

articles.headline: Sorry, the World’s Biggest Bike Maker Can’t Help You Buy a Bike Right Now
articles.snippet: The pandemic has created a bicycle boom — and a shortage. Giant, the Taiwanese juggernaut, is trying to meet demand while navigating the politics of trade.
articles.abstract: The pandemic has created a bicycle boom — and a shortage. Giant, the Taiwanese juggernaut, is trying to meet demand while navigating the politics of trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAICHUNG, Taiwan — Because gyms are closed and we could all use a little more exercise; because we are avoiding buses and trains; because we are in need of outdoor group activities; or perhaps just because the pandemic has made us crave simple pleasures like the wind against our faces, bicycle sales are soaring around the world.
articles.byline: By Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: Coronavirus Doctors Battle Another Scourge: Misinformation
articles.snippet: Physicians say they regularly treat people more inclined to believe what they read on Facebook than what a medical professional tells them.
articles.abstract: Physicians say they regularly treat people more inclined to believe what they read on Facebook than what a medical professional tells them.
articles.lead_paragraph: An emergency room doctor in Illinois was accused in April of profiting from naming coronavirus as the cause of a patient’s death, a rumor spreading online.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano

articles.headline: Trump’s Attacks on TikTok and WeChat Could Further Fracture the Internet
articles.snippet: The president’s restrictions on Chinese tech may be part of an eye-for-an-eye logic called reciprocity. The price could be a global patchwork of online fiefs.
articles.abstract: The president’s restrictions on Chinese tech may be part of an eye-for-an-eye logic called reciprocity. The price could be a global patchwork of online fiefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — China and the United States once acted like opposites when it came to governing the internet.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, Paul Mozur and Raymond Zhong

articles.headline: No Longer Cowed, Belarus Has Message for Once-Mighty Dictator: ‘Go Away!’
articles.snippet: As even his base starts to desert him after protests over a rigged election were met with brutality, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s 26-year grip on power may be slipping.
articles.abstract: As even his base starts to desert him after protests over a rigged election were met with brutality, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko’s 26-year grip on power may be slipping.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINSK, Belarus — In an age of ascendant strongman leaders, President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus is suddenly looking surprisingly weak.
articles.byline: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
